introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand and be able apply tests of significance.

section.title: Testing for Significance
section.p: The statement to be tested is called the null hypothesis. We design the test to assess the strength of the evidence against the null hypothesis.

Assuming the null hypothesis is true, the probability that the observed outcome would take a value as extreme or more extreme than what we actually observe is called the P-value of a test. Small P-values tell us that the evidence against the null hypothesis is strong.

section.title: Inference for a Population Proportion
section.p: Suppose that we have a large population that contains a proportion of p successes, we can estimate p with a sample proportion. Suppose that we select a simple random sample of size n from the population. The sample proportion of successes is defined to be \hat{p} = \frac{\text{number of successes in the sample}}{n}. As the sample size increases, the sampling distribution of \hat{p} is approximately the normal distribution. The mean of the sampling distribution is p and the standard deviation is \sqrt{\frac{p(1- p)}{n}}.
